trans-unit.source: Authentication for the Azure Storage Services
trans-unit.target: Authentication for the Azure Storage Services

trans-unit.source: Every request made against a storage service must be authenticated, unless the request is for a blob or container resource that has been made available for public or signed access.
trans-unit.target: Every request made against a storage service must be authenticated, unless the request is for a blob or container resource that has been made available for public or signed access.

trans-unit.source: The Microsoft Azure storage services support both HTTP and HTTPS; however, using HTTPS is highly recommended.
trans-unit.target: The Microsoft Azure storage services support both HTTP and HTTPS; however, using HTTPS is highly recommended.

trans-unit.source: The Blob, Queue, Table, and File services support the following Shared Key authentication schemes for version 2009-09-19 and later (for Blob, Queue, and Table service) and version 2014-02-14 and later (for File service):
trans-unit.target: The Blob, Queue, Table, and File services support the following Shared Key authentication schemes for version 2009-09-19 and later (for Blob, Queue, and Table service) and version 2014-02-14 and later (for File service):

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Shared Key for Blob, Queue, and File Services.</embeddedLabel> Use the Shared Key authentication scheme to make requests against the Blob, Queue, and File services.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Shared Key for Blob, Queue, and File Services.</embeddedLabel> Use the Shared Key authentication scheme to make requests against the Blob, Queue, and File services.

trans-unit.source: Shared Key authentication in version 2009-09-19 and later supports an augmented signature string for enhanced security and requires that you update your service to authenticate using this augmented signature.
trans-unit.target: Shared Key authentication in version 2009-09-19 and later supports an augmented signature string for enhanced security and requires that you update your service to authenticate using this augmented signature.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Shared Key for Table Service.</embeddedLabel> Use the Shared Key authentication scheme to make requests against the Table service using the REST API.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Shared Key for Table Service.</embeddedLabel> Use the Shared Key authentication scheme to make requests against the Table service using the REST API.

trans-unit.source: Shared Key authentication for the Table service in version 2009-09-19 and later uses the same signature string as in previous versions of the Table service.
trans-unit.target: Shared Key authentication for the Table service in version 2009-09-19 and later uses the same signature string as in previous versions of the Table service.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Shared Key Lite.</embeddedLabel> Use the Shared Key Lite authentication scheme to make requests against the Blob, Queue, Table, and File services.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Shared Key Lite.</embeddedLabel> Use the Shared Key Lite authentication scheme to make requests against the Blob, Queue, Table, and File services.

trans-unit.source: For version 2009-09-19 and later of the Blob and Queue services, Shared Key Lite authentication supports using a signature string identical to what was supported against Shared Key in previous versions of the Blob and Queue services.
trans-unit.target: For version 2009-09-19 and later of the Blob and Queue services, Shared Key Lite authentication supports using a signature string identical to what was supported against Shared Key in previous versions of the Blob and Queue services.

trans-unit.source: You can therefore use Shared Key Lite to make requests against the Blob and Queue services without updating your signature string.
trans-unit.target: You can therefore use Shared Key Lite to make requests against the Blob and Queue services without updating your signature string.

trans-unit.source: An authenticated request requires two headers: the <parameterReference>Date</parameterReference> or <parameterReference>x-ms-date</parameterReference> header and the <parameterReference>Authorization</parameterReference> header.
trans-unit.target: An authenticated request requires two headers: the <parameterReference>Date</parameterReference> or <parameterReference>x-ms-date</parameterReference> header and the <parameterReference>Authorization</parameterReference> header.

trans-unit.source: The following sections describe how to construct these headers.
trans-unit.target: The following sections describe how to construct these headers.

trans-unit.source: A container or blob may be made available for public access by setting a container's permissions.
trans-unit.target: A container or blob may be made available for public access by setting a container's permissions.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <legacyLink xlink:href="c30f3d25-67a0-47b4-a05e-afee4126c7c8" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Manage Access to Azure Storage Resources</legacyLink>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <legacyLink xlink:href="c30f3d25-67a0-47b4-a05e-afee4126c7c8" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Manage Access to Azure Storage Resources</legacyLink>.

trans-unit.source: A container, blob, queue, or table may be available for signed access via a shared access signature; a shared access signature is authenticated through a different mechanism.
trans-unit.target: A container, blob, queue, or table may be available for signed access via a shared access signature; a shared access signature is authenticated through a different mechanism.

trans-unit.source: See <link xlink:href="98f3411e-d85d-4be9-809e-135b3d4ed436" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Delegating Access with a Shared Access Signature (REST API)</link> for more details.
trans-unit.target: See <link xlink:href="98f3411e-d85d-4be9-809e-135b3d4ed436" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Delegating Access with a Shared Access Signature (REST API)</link> for more details.

trans-unit.source: Specifying the Date Header
trans-unit.target: Specifying the Date Header

trans-unit.source: All authenticated requests must include the Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) timestamp for the request.
trans-unit.target: All authenticated requests must include the Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) timestamp for the request.

trans-unit.source: You can specify the timestamp either in the <parameterReference>x-ms-date</parameterReference> header, or in the standard HTTP/HTTPS <parameterReference>Date</parameterReference> header.
trans-unit.target: You can specify the timestamp either in the <parameterReference>x-ms-date</parameterReference> header, or in the standard HTTP/HTTPS <parameterReference>Date</parameterReference> header.

trans-unit.source: If both headers are specified on the request, the value of <parameterReference>x-ms-date</parameterReference> is used as the request's time of creation.
trans-unit.target: If both headers are specified on the request, the value of <parameterReference>x-ms-date</parameterReference> is used as the request's time of creation.

trans-unit.source: The storage services ensure that a request is no older than 15 minutes by the time it reaches the service.
trans-unit.target: The storage services ensure that a request is no older than 15 minutes by the time it reaches the service.

trans-unit.source: This guards against certain security attacks, including replay attacks.
trans-unit.target: This guards against certain security attacks, including replay attacks.

trans-unit.source: When this check fails, the server returns response code 403 (Forbidden).
trans-unit.target: When this check fails, the server returns response code 403 (Forbidden).

trans-unit.source: The <parameterReference>x-ms-date</parameterReference> header is provided because some HTTP client libraries and proxies automatically set the <parameterReference>Date</parameterReference> header, and do not give the developer an opportunity to read its value in order to include it in the authenticated request.
trans-unit.target: The <parameterReference>x-ms-date</parameterReference> header is provided because some HTTP client libraries and proxies automatically set the <parameterReference>Date</parameterReference> header, and do not give the developer an opportunity to read its value in order to include it in the authenticated request.

trans-unit.source: If you set <parameterReference>x-ms-date</parameterReference>, construct the signature with an empty value for the <parameterReference>Date</parameterReference> header.
trans-unit.target: If you set <parameterReference>x-ms-date</parameterReference>, construct the signature with an empty value for the <parameterReference>Date</parameterReference> header.

trans-unit.source: Specifying the Authorization Header
trans-unit.target: Specifying the Authorization Header

trans-unit.source: An authenticated request must include the <parameterReference>Authorization</parameterReference> header.
trans-unit.target: An authenticated request must include the <parameterReference>Authorization</parameterReference> header.

trans-unit.source: If this header is not included, the request is anonymous and may only succeed against a container or blob that is marked for public access, or against a container, blob, queue, or table for which a shared access signature has been provided for delegated access.
trans-unit.target: If this header is not included, the request is anonymous and may only succeed against a container or blob that is marked for public access, or against a container, blob, queue, or table for which a shared access signature has been provided for delegated access.

trans-unit.source: To authenticate a request, you must sign the request with the key for the account that is making the request and pass that signature as part of the request.
trans-unit.target: To authenticate a request, you must sign the request with the key for the account that is making the request and pass that signature as part of the request.

trans-unit.source: The format for the <parameterReference>Authorization</parameterReference> header is as follows:
trans-unit.target: The format for the <parameterReference>Authorization</parameterReference> header is as follows:

trans-unit.source: where <codeInline>SharedKey</codeInline> or <codeInline>SharedKeyLite</codeInline> is the name of the authorization scheme, <codeInline>AccountName</codeInline> is the name of the account requesting the resource, and <codeInline>Signature</codeInline> is a Hash-based Message Authentication Code (HMAC) constructed from the request and computed by using the SHA256 algorithm, and then encoded by using Base64 encoding.
trans-unit.target: where <codeInline>SharedKey</codeInline> or <codeInline>SharedKeyLite</codeInline> is the name of the authorization scheme, <codeInline>AccountName</codeInline> is the name of the account requesting the resource, and <codeInline>Signature</codeInline> is a Hash-based Message Authentication Code (HMAC) constructed from the request and computed by using the SHA256 algorithm, and then encoded by using Base64 encoding.

trans-unit.source: It is possible to request a resource that resides beneath a different account, if that resource is publicly accessible.
trans-unit.target: It is possible to request a resource that resides beneath a different account, if that resource is publicly accessible.

trans-unit.source: The following sections describe how to construct the <parameterReference>Authorization</parameterReference> header.
trans-unit.target: The following sections describe how to construct the <parameterReference>Authorization</parameterReference> header.

trans-unit.source: Constructing the Signature String
trans-unit.target: Constructing the Signature String

trans-unit.source: How you construct the signature string depends on which service and version you are authenticating against and which authentication scheme you are using.
trans-unit.target: How you construct the signature string depends on which service and version you are authenticating against and which authentication scheme you are using.

trans-unit.source: When constructing the signature string, keep in mind the following:
trans-unit.target: When constructing the signature string, keep in mind the following:

trans-unit.source: The VERB portion of the string is the HTTP verb, such as GET or PUT, and must be uppercase.
trans-unit.target: The VERB portion of the string is the HTTP verb, such as GET or PUT, and must be uppercase.

trans-unit.source: For Shared Key authentication for the Blob, Queue, and File services, each header included in the signature string may appear only once.
trans-unit.target: For Shared Key authentication for the Blob, Queue, and File services, each header included in the signature string may appear only once.

trans-unit.source: If any header is duplicated, the service returns status code 400 (Bad Request).
trans-unit.target: If any header is duplicated, the service returns status code 400 (Bad Request).

trans-unit.source: The values of all standard HTTP headers must be included in the string in the order shown in the signature format, without the header names.
trans-unit.target: The values of all standard HTTP headers must be included in the string in the order shown in the signature format, without the header names.

trans-unit.source: These headers may be empty if they are not being specified as part of the request; in that case, only the new-line character is required.
trans-unit.target: These headers may be empty if they are not being specified as part of the request; in that case, only the new-line character is required.

trans-unit.source: If the <parameterReference>x-ms-date</parameterReference> header is specified, you may ignore the <parameterReference>Date</parameterReference> header, regardless of whether it is specified on the request, and simply specify an empty line for the <parameterReference>Date</parameterReference> portion of the signature string.
trans-unit.target: If the <parameterReference>x-ms-date</parameterReference> header is specified, you may ignore the <parameterReference>Date</parameterReference> header, regardless of whether it is specified on the request, and simply specify an empty line for the <parameterReference>Date</parameterReference> portion of the signature string.

trans-unit.source: In this case, follow the instructions in the <legacyLink xlink:href="#Constructing_Element" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Constructing the CanonicalizedHeaders Element</legacyLink> section for adding the <parameterReference>x-ms-date</parameterReference> header.
trans-unit.target: In this case, follow the instructions in the <legacyLink xlink:href="#Constructing_Element" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Constructing the CanonicalizedHeaders Element</legacyLink> section for adding the <parameterReference>x-ms-date</parameterReference> header.

trans-unit.source: Note that it is acceptable to specify both <parameterReference>x-ms-date</parameterReference> and <parameterReference>Date</parameterReference>; in this case, the service uses the value of <parameterReference>x-ms-date</parameterReference>.
trans-unit.target: Note that it is acceptable to specify both <parameterReference>x-ms-date</parameterReference> and <parameterReference>Date</parameterReference>; in this case, the service uses the value of <parameterReference>x-ms-date</parameterReference>.

trans-unit.source: If the <parameterReference>x-ms-date</parameterReference> header is not specified, specify the <parameterReference>Date</parameterReference> header in the signature string, without including the header name.
trans-unit.target: If the <parameterReference>x-ms-date</parameterReference> header is not specified, specify the <parameterReference>Date</parameterReference> header in the signature string, without including the header name.

trans-unit.source: All new-line characters (\n) shown are required within the signature string.
trans-unit.target: All new-line characters (\n) shown are required within the signature string.

trans-unit.source: The signature string includes canonicalized headers and canonicalized resource strings.
trans-unit.target: The signature string includes canonicalized headers and canonicalized resource strings.

trans-unit.source: Canonicalizing these strings puts them into a standard format that is recognized by Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: Canonicalizing these strings puts them into a standard format that is recognized by Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: For detailed information on constructing the <codeInline>CanonicalizedHeaders</codeInline> and <codeInline>CanonicalizedResource</codeInline> strings that make up part of the signature string, see the appropriate sections later in this topic.
trans-unit.target: For detailed information on constructing the <codeInline>CanonicalizedHeaders</codeInline> and <codeInline>CanonicalizedResource</codeInline> strings that make up part of the signature string, see the appropriate sections later in this topic.

trans-unit.source: Blob, Queue, and File Services (Shared Key Authentication)
trans-unit.target: Blob, Queue, and File Services (Shared Key Authentication)

trans-unit.source: To encode the Shared Key signature string for a request against the 2009-09-19 version and later of the Blob or Queue service, and version 2014-02-14 and later of the File service, use the following format:
trans-unit.target: To encode the Shared Key signature string for a request against the 2009-09-19 version and later of the Blob or Queue service, and version 2014-02-14 and later of the File service, use the following format:

trans-unit.source: The following example shows a signature string for a <link xlink:href="a3e943b4-5745-4e64-9d6f-728bbefbd5ee" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Get Blob</link> operation.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows a signature string for a <link xlink:href="a3e943b4-5745-4e64-9d6f-728bbefbd5ee" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Get Blob</link> operation.

trans-unit.source: Note that where there is no header value, the new-line character only is specified.
trans-unit.target: Note that where there is no header value, the new-line character only is specified.

trans-unit.source: Breaking this down line-by-line shows each portion of the same string:
trans-unit.target: Breaking this down line-by-line shows each portion of the same string:

trans-unit.source: Next, encode this string by using the HMAC-SHA256 algorithm over the UTF-8-encoded signature string, construct the <parameterReference>Authorization</parameterReference> header, and add the header to the request.
trans-unit.target: Next, encode this string by using the HMAC-SHA256 algorithm over the UTF-8-encoded signature string, construct the <parameterReference>Authorization</parameterReference> header, and add the header to the request.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows the <parameterReference>Authorization</parameterReference> header for the same operation:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows the <parameterReference>Authorization</parameterReference> header for the same operation:

trans-unit.source: Note that in order to use Shared Key authentication with version 2009-09-19 and later of the Blob and Queue services, you must update your code to use this augmented signature string.
trans-unit.target: Note that in order to use Shared Key authentication with version 2009-09-19 and later of the Blob and Queue services, you must update your code to use this augmented signature string.

trans-unit.source: If you prefer to migrate your code to version 2009-09-19 or later of the Blob and Queue services with the fewest possible changes, you can modify your existing <parameterReference>Authorization</parameterReference> headers to use Shared Key Lite instead of Shared Key.
trans-unit.target: If you prefer to migrate your code to version 2009-09-19 or later of the Blob and Queue services with the fewest possible changes, you can modify your existing <parameterReference>Authorization</parameterReference> headers to use Shared Key Lite instead of Shared Key.

trans-unit.source: The signature format required by Shared Key Lite is identical to that required for Shared Key by versions of the Blob and Queue services prior to 2009-09-19.
trans-unit.target: The signature format required by Shared Key Lite is identical to that required for Shared Key by versions of the Blob and Queue services prior to 2009-09-19.

trans-unit.source: If you are accessing the secondary location in a storage account for which read-access geo-replication (RA-GRS) is enabled, do not include the <codeInline>-secondary</codeInline> designation in the authorization header.
trans-unit.target: If you are accessing the secondary location in a storage account for which read-access geo-replication (RA-GRS) is enabled, do not include the <codeInline>-secondary</codeInline> designation in the authorization header.

trans-unit.source: For authorization purposes, the account name is always the name of the primary location, even for secondary access.
trans-unit.target: For authorization purposes, the account name is always the name of the primary location, even for secondary access.

trans-unit.source: Content-Length Header in Version 2015-02-21 and Later
trans-unit.target: Content-Length Header in Version 2015-02-21 and Later

trans-unit.source: When using version 2015-02-21 or later, if <parameterReference>Content-Length</parameterReference> is zero, then set the <parameterReference>Content-Length</parameterReference> part of the <codeInline>StringToSign</codeInline> to an empty string.
trans-unit.target: When using version 2015-02-21 or later, if <parameterReference>Content-Length</parameterReference> is zero, then set the <parameterReference>Content-Length</parameterReference> part of the <codeInline>StringToSign</codeInline> to an empty string.

trans-unit.source: For example, for the following request, the value of the <parameterReference>Content-Length</parameterReference> header is omitted from the <codeInline>StringToSign</codeInline> when it is zero.
trans-unit.target: For example, for the following request, the value of the <parameterReference>Content-Length</parameterReference> header is omitted from the <codeInline>StringToSign</codeInline> when it is zero.

trans-unit.source: The <codeInline>StringToSign</codeInline> is constructed as follows:
trans-unit.target: The <codeInline>StringToSign</codeInline> is constructed as follows:

trans-unit.source: Whereas in versions prior to 2015-02-21, the <codeInline>StringToSign</codeInline> must include the zero value for <parameterReference>Content-Length</parameterReference>:
trans-unit.target: Whereas in versions prior to 2015-02-21, the <codeInline>StringToSign</codeInline> must include the zero value for <parameterReference>Content-Length</parameterReference>:

trans-unit.source: Table Service (Shared Key Authentication)
trans-unit.target: Table Service (Shared Key Authentication)

trans-unit.source: You must use Shared Key authentication to authenticate a request made against the Table service if your service is using the REST API to make the request.
trans-unit.target: You must use Shared Key authentication to authenticate a request made against the Table service if your service is using the REST API to make the request.

trans-unit.source: The format of the signature string for Shared Key against the Table service is the same for all versions.
trans-unit.target: The format of the signature string for Shared Key against the Table service is the same for all versions.

trans-unit.source: Note that the Shared Key signature string for a request against the Table service differs slightly from that for a request against the Blob or Queue service, in that it does not include the <codeInline>CanonicalizedHeaders</codeInline> portion of the string.
trans-unit.target: Note that the Shared Key signature string for a request against the Table service differs slightly from that for a request against the Blob or Queue service, in that it does not include the <codeInline>CanonicalizedHeaders</codeInline> portion of the string.

trans-unit.source: Additionally, the <parameterReference>Date</parameterReference> header in this case is never empty even if the request sets the <parameterReference>x-ms-date</parameterReference> header.
trans-unit.target: Additionally, the <parameterReference>Date</parameterReference> header in this case is never empty even if the request sets the <parameterReference>x-ms-date</parameterReference> header.

trans-unit.source: If the request sets <parameterReference>x-ms-date</parameterReference>, that value is also used for the value of the <parameterReference>Date</parameterReference> header.
trans-unit.target: If the request sets <parameterReference>x-ms-date</parameterReference>, that value is also used for the value of the <parameterReference>Date</parameterReference> header.

trans-unit.source: To encode the signature string for a request against the Table service made using the REST API, use the following format:
trans-unit.target: To encode the signature string for a request against the Table service made using the REST API, use the following format:

trans-unit.source: Beginning with version 2009-09-19, the Table service requires that all REST calls include the <parameterReference>DataServiceVersion</parameterReference> and <parameterReference>MaxDataServiceVersion</parameterReference> headers.
trans-unit.target: Beginning with version 2009-09-19, the Table service requires that all REST calls include the <parameterReference>DataServiceVersion</parameterReference> and <parameterReference>MaxDataServiceVersion</parameterReference> headers.

trans-unit.source: See <link xlink:href="086d4db0-0743-4987-b8a7-2cd15090dfd6" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Setting the OData Data Service Version Headers</link> for more information.
trans-unit.target: See <link xlink:href="086d4db0-0743-4987-b8a7-2cd15090dfd6" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Setting the OData Data Service Version Headers</link> for more information.

trans-unit.source: Blob, Queue, and File Service (Shared Key Lite Authentication)
trans-unit.target: Blob, Queue, and File Service (Shared Key Lite Authentication)

trans-unit.source: You may use Shared Key Lite authentication to authenticate a request made against the 2009-09-19 version and later of the Blob and Queue services, and version 2014-02-14 and later of the File services.
trans-unit.target: You may use Shared Key Lite authentication to authenticate a request made against the 2009-09-19 version and later of the Blob and Queue services, and version 2014-02-14 and later of the File services.

trans-unit.source: The signature string for Shared Key Lite is identical to the signature string required for Shared Key authentication in versions of the Blob and Queue services prior to 2009-09-19.
trans-unit.target: The signature string for Shared Key Lite is identical to the signature string required for Shared Key authentication in versions of the Blob and Queue services prior to 2009-09-19.

trans-unit.source: So if you wish to migrate your code with the least number of changes to version 2009-09-19 of the Blob and Queue services, you can modify your code to use Shared Key Lite, without changing the signature string itself.
trans-unit.target: So if you wish to migrate your code with the least number of changes to version 2009-09-19 of the Blob and Queue services, you can modify your code to use Shared Key Lite, without changing the signature string itself.

trans-unit.source: Note that by using Shared Key Lite, you will not gain the enhanced security functionality provided by using Shared Key with version 2009-09-19 and later.
trans-unit.target: Note that by using Shared Key Lite, you will not gain the enhanced security functionality provided by using Shared Key with version 2009-09-19 and later.

trans-unit.source: To encode the signature string for a request against the Blob or Queue service, use the following format:
trans-unit.target: To encode the signature string for a request against the Blob or Queue service, use the following format:

trans-unit.source: The following example shows a signature string for a <link xlink:href="b213c30f-8d30-4718-ba77-2030f3009719" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Put Blob</link> operation.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows a signature string for a <link xlink:href="b213c30f-8d30-4718-ba77-2030f3009719" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Put Blob</link> operation.

trans-unit.source: Note that the Content-MD5 header line is empty.
trans-unit.target: Note that the Content-MD5 header line is empty.

trans-unit.source: The headers shown in the string are name-value pairs that specify custom metadata values for the new blob.
trans-unit.target: The headers shown in the string are name-value pairs that specify custom metadata values for the new blob.

trans-unit.source: Next, encode this string by using the HMAC-SHA256 algorithm over the UTF-8-encoded signature string, construct the <parameterReference>Authorization</parameterReference> header, and add the header to the request.
trans-unit.target: Next, encode this string by using the HMAC-SHA256 algorithm over the UTF-8-encoded signature string, construct the <parameterReference>Authorization</parameterReference> header, and add the header to the request.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows the <parameterReference>Authorization</parameterReference> header for the same operation:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows the <parameterReference>Authorization</parameterReference> header for the same operation:

trans-unit.source: Table Service (Shared Key Lite Authentication)
trans-unit.target: Table Service (Shared Key Lite Authentication)

trans-unit.source: You can use Shared Key Lite authentication to authenticate a request made against any version of the Table service.
trans-unit.target: You can use Shared Key Lite authentication to authenticate a request made against any version of the Table service.

trans-unit.source: To encode the signature string for a request against the Table service using Shared Key Lite, use the following format:
trans-unit.target: To encode the signature string for a request against the Table service using Shared Key Lite, use the following format:

trans-unit.source: The following example shows a signature string for a <link xlink:href="e7b7c22f-39d1-46b1-9f3a-0ccaeabde95a" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Create Table</link> operation.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows a signature string for a <link xlink:href="e7b7c22f-39d1-46b1-9f3a-0ccaeabde95a" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Create Table</link> operation.

trans-unit.source: Next, encode this string by using the HMAC-SHA256 algorithm, construct the <parameterReference>Authorization</parameterReference> header, and then add the header to the request.
trans-unit.target: Next, encode this string by using the HMAC-SHA256 algorithm, construct the <parameterReference>Authorization</parameterReference> header, and then add the header to the request.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows the <parameterReference>Authorization</parameterReference> header for the same operation:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows the <parameterReference>Authorization</parameterReference> header for the same operation:

trans-unit.source: Constructing the Canonicalized Headers String
trans-unit.target: Constructing the Canonicalized Headers String

trans-unit.source: To construct the <codeInline>CanonicalizedHeaders</codeInline> portion of the signature string, follow these steps:
trans-unit.target: To construct the <codeInline>CanonicalizedHeaders</codeInline> portion of the signature string, follow these steps:

trans-unit.source: Retrieve all headers for the resource that begin with <parameterReference>x-ms-</parameterReference>, including the <parameterReference>x-ms-date</parameterReference> header.
trans-unit.target: Retrieve all headers for the resource that begin with <parameterReference>x-ms-</parameterReference>, including the <parameterReference>x-ms-date</parameterReference> header.

trans-unit.source: Convert each HTTP header name to lowercase.
trans-unit.target: Convert each HTTP header name to lowercase.

trans-unit.source: Sort the headers lexicographically by header name, in ascending order.
trans-unit.target: Sort the headers lexicographically by header name, in ascending order.

trans-unit.source: Each header may appear only once in the string.
trans-unit.target: Each header may appear only once in the string.

trans-unit.source: <externalLink><linkText>Lexicographical ordering</linkText><linkUri>http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lexicographical_order</linkUri></externalLink> may not always coincide with conventional alphabetical ordering.
trans-unit.target: <externalLink><linkText>Lexicographical ordering</linkText><linkUri>http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lexicographical_order</linkUri></externalLink> may not always coincide with conventional alphabetical ordering.

trans-unit.source: Unfold the string by replacing any breaking white space with a single space.
trans-unit.target: Unfold the string by replacing any breaking white space with a single space.

trans-unit.source: Trim any white space around the colon in the header.
trans-unit.target: Trim any white space around the colon in the header.

trans-unit.source: Finally, append a new-line character to each canonicalized header in the resulting list.
trans-unit.target: Finally, append a new-line character to each canonicalized header in the resulting list.

trans-unit.source: Construct the <codeInline>CanonicalizedHeaders</codeInline> string by concatenating all headers in this list into a single string.
trans-unit.target: Construct the <codeInline>CanonicalizedHeaders</codeInline> string by concatenating all headers in this list into a single string.

trans-unit.target: The following shows an example of a canonicalized headers string:

trans-unit.source: Constructing the Canonicalized Resource String
trans-unit.target: Constructing the Canonicalized Resource String

trans-unit.source: The <codeInline>CanonicalizedResource</codeInline> part of the signature string represents the storage services resource targeted by the request.
trans-unit.target: The <codeInline>CanonicalizedResource</codeInline> part of the signature string represents the storage services resource targeted by the request.

trans-unit.source: Any portion of the <codeInline>CanonicalizedResource</codeInline> string that is derived from the resource's URI should be encoded exactly as it is in the URI.
trans-unit.target: Any portion of the <codeInline>CanonicalizedResource</codeInline> string that is derived from the resource's URI should be encoded exactly as it is in the URI.

trans-unit.source: There are two supported formats for the <codeInline>CanonicalizedResource</codeInline> string:
trans-unit.target: There are two supported formats for the <codeInline>CanonicalizedResource</codeInline> string:

trans-unit.source: A format that supports Shared Key authentication for version 2009-09-19 and later of the Blob and Queue services, and for version 2014-02-14 and later of the File service.
trans-unit.target: A format that supports Shared Key authentication for version 2009-09-19 and later of the Blob and Queue services, and for version 2014-02-14 and later of the File service.

trans-unit.source: A format that supports Shared Key and Shared Key Lite for all versions of the Table service, and Shared Key Lite for version 2009-09-19 and later of the Blob and Queue services.
trans-unit.target: A format that supports Shared Key and Shared Key Lite for all versions of the Table service, and Shared Key Lite for version 2009-09-19 and later of the Blob and Queue services.

trans-unit.source: This format is identical to that used with previous versions of the storage services.
trans-unit.target: This format is identical to that used with previous versions of the storage services.

trans-unit.source: For help constructing the URI for the resource you are accessing, see one of the following topics:
trans-unit.target: For help constructing the URI for the resource you are accessing, see one of the following topics:

trans-unit.source: Blob service: <link xlink:href="d525950c-17ba-4b3b-9ed1-19a2145f769a" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Naming and Referencing Containers, Blobs, and Metadata</link>
trans-unit.target: Blob service: <link xlink:href="d525950c-17ba-4b3b-9ed1-19a2145f769a" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Naming and Referencing Containers, Blobs, and Metadata</link>

trans-unit.source: Queue service: <link xlink:href="76b63549-2008-4443-865c-78c7d1472253" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Addressing Queue Service Resources</link>
trans-unit.target: Queue service: <link xlink:href="76b63549-2008-4443-865c-78c7d1472253" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Addressing Queue Service Resources</link>

trans-unit.source: Table service: <link xlink:href="238c4c0e-da32-416d-99ba-c02f24f00cfb" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Addressing Table Service Resources</link>
trans-unit.target: Table service: <link xlink:href="238c4c0e-da32-416d-99ba-c02f24f00cfb" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Addressing Table Service Resources</link>

trans-unit.source: File service: <link xlink:href="f38d4c69-cb50-4ef3-a8a3-276341689769" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Naming and Referencing Shares, Directories, Files, and Metadata</link>
trans-unit.target: File service: <link xlink:href="f38d4c69-cb50-4ef3-a8a3-276341689769" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Naming and Referencing Shares, Directories, Files, and Metadata</link>

trans-unit.source: If your storage account is replicated with read-access geo-replication (RA-GRS), and you are accessing a resource in the secondary location, do not include the <codeInline>secondary</codeInline> designation in the <codeInline>CanonicalizedResource</codeInline> string.
trans-unit.target: If your storage account is replicated with read-access geo-replication (RA-GRS), and you are accessing a resource in the secondary location, do not include the <codeInline>secondary</codeInline> designation in the <codeInline>CanonicalizedResource</codeInline> string.

trans-unit.source: The resource URI used in the <codeInline>CanonicalizedResource</codeInline> string URI should be the URI of the resource at the primary location.
trans-unit.target: The resource URI used in the <codeInline>CanonicalizedResource</codeInline> string URI should be the URI of the resource at the primary location.

trans-unit.source: If you are authenticating against the storage emulator, the account name will appear twice in the <codeInline>CanonicalizedResource</codeInline> string.
trans-unit.target: If you are authenticating against the storage emulator, the account name will appear twice in the <codeInline>CanonicalizedResource</codeInline> string.

trans-unit.source: This is expected.
trans-unit.target: This is expected.

trans-unit.source: If you are authenticating against Azure storage services, the account name will appear only one time in the <codeInline>CanonicalizedResource</codeInline> string.
trans-unit.target: If you are authenticating against Azure storage services, the account name will appear only one time in the <codeInline>CanonicalizedResource</codeInline> string.

trans-unit.source: 2009-09-19 and later Shared Key Format
trans-unit.target: 2009-09-19 and later Shared Key Format

trans-unit.source: This format supports Shared Key authentication for the 2009-09-19 version and later of the Blob and Queue services, and the 2014-02-14 version and later of the File services.
trans-unit.target: This format supports Shared Key authentication for the 2009-09-19 version and later of the Blob and Queue services, and the 2014-02-14 version and later of the File services.

trans-unit.source: Construct the <codeInline>CanonicalizedResource</codeInline> string in this format as follows:
trans-unit.target: Construct the <codeInline>CanonicalizedResource</codeInline> string in this format as follows:

trans-unit.source: Beginning with an empty string (""), append a forward slash (/), followed by the name of the account that owns the resource being accessed.
trans-unit.target: Beginning with an empty string (""), append a forward slash (/), followed by the name of the account that owns the resource being accessed.

trans-unit.source: Append the resource's encoded URI path, without any query parameters.
trans-unit.target: Append the resource's encoded URI path, without any query parameters.

trans-unit.source: Append a new-line character (\n) after the resource name.
trans-unit.target: Append a new-line character (\n) after the resource name.

trans-unit.source: Retrieve all query parameters on the resource URI, including the <parameterReference>comp</parameterReference> parameter if it exists.
trans-unit.target: Retrieve all query parameters on the resource URI, including the <parameterReference>comp</parameterReference> parameter if it exists.

trans-unit.source: Convert all parameter names to lowercase.
trans-unit.target: Convert all parameter names to lowercase.

trans-unit.source: Sort the query parameters lexicographically by parameter name, in ascending order.
trans-unit.target: Sort the query parameters lexicographically by parameter name, in ascending order.

trans-unit.source: URL-decode each query parameter name and value.
trans-unit.target: URL-decode each query parameter name and value.

trans-unit.source: Append each query parameter name and value to the string in the following format, making sure to include the colon (:) between the name and the value:
trans-unit.target: Append each query parameter name and value to the string in the following format, making sure to include the colon (:) between the name and the value:

trans-unit.source: If a query parameter has more than one value, sort all values lexicographically, then include them in a comma-separated list:
trans-unit.target: If a query parameter has more than one value, sort all values lexicographically, then include them in a comma-separated list:

trans-unit.source: Append a new-line character (\n) after each name-value pair.
trans-unit.target: Append a new-line character (\n) after each name-value pair.

trans-unit.source: Keep in mind the following rules for constructing the canonicalized resource string:
trans-unit.target: Keep in mind the following rules for constructing the canonicalized resource string:

trans-unit.source: Avoid using the new-line character (\n) in values for query parameters.
trans-unit.target: Avoid using the new-line character (\n) in values for query parameters.

trans-unit.source: If it must be used, ensure that it does not affect the format of the canonicalized resource string.
trans-unit.target: If it must be used, ensure that it does not affect the format of the canonicalized resource string.

trans-unit.source: Avoid using commas in query parameter values.
trans-unit.target: Avoid using commas in query parameter values.

trans-unit.source: Here are some examples that show the <codeInline>CanonicalizedResource</codeInline> portion of the signature string, as it may be constructed from a given request URI:
trans-unit.target: Here are some examples that show the <codeInline>CanonicalizedResource</codeInline> portion of the signature string, as it may be constructed from a given request URI:

trans-unit.source: 2009-09-19 and later Shared Key Lite and Table service format
trans-unit.target: 2009-09-19 and later Shared Key Lite and Table service format

trans-unit.source: This format supports Shared Key and Shared Key Lite for all versions of the Table service, and Shared Key Lite for version 2009-09-19 and later of the Blob and Queue services and version 2014-02-14 and later of the File service.
trans-unit.target: This format supports Shared Key and Shared Key Lite for all versions of the Table service, and Shared Key Lite for version 2009-09-19 and later of the Blob and Queue services and version 2014-02-14 and later of the File service.

trans-unit.source: This format is identical to that used with previous versions of the storage services.
trans-unit.target: This format is identical to that used with previous versions of the storage services.

trans-unit.source: Construct the <codeInline>CanonicalizedResource</codeInline> string in this format as follows:
trans-unit.target: Construct the <codeInline>CanonicalizedResource</codeInline> string in this format as follows:

trans-unit.source: Beginning with an empty string (""), append a forward slash (/), followed by the name of the account that owns the resource being accessed.
trans-unit.target: Beginning with an empty string (""), append a forward slash (/), followed by the name of the account that owns the resource being accessed.

trans-unit.source: Append the resource's encoded URI path.
trans-unit.target: Append the resource's encoded URI path.

trans-unit.source: If the request URI addresses a component of the resource, append the appropriate query string.
trans-unit.target: If the request URI addresses a component of the resource, append the appropriate query string.

trans-unit.source: The query string should include the question mark and the <parameterReference>comp</parameterReference> parameter (for example, <codeInline>?comp=metadata</codeInline>).
trans-unit.target: The query string should include the question mark and the <parameterReference>comp</parameterReference> parameter (for example, <codeInline>?comp=metadata</codeInline>).

trans-unit.source: No other parameters should be included on the query string.
trans-unit.target: No other parameters should be included on the query string.

trans-unit.source: Encoding the Signature
trans-unit.target: Encoding the Signature

trans-unit.source: To encode the signature, call the HMAC-SHA256 algorithm on the UTF-8-encoded signature string and encode the result as Base64.
trans-unit.target: To encode the signature, call the HMAC-SHA256 algorithm on the UTF-8-encoded signature string and encode the result as Base64.
